hero.title: Your Personalized Senior Frontend Engineer Roadmap is Ready!

radarAxes.label: Skills
radarAxes.title: Skill Breadth
radarAxes.description: Percentage of frontend skills you've selected. Shows how well-rounded you are.

radarAxes.label: DSA
radarAxes.title: Data Structures & Algorithms
radarAxes.description: Problem-solving ability. Essential for technical interviews and logic building.

radarAxes.label: Frameworks
radarAxes.title: Modern Frameworks
radarAxes.description: Proficiency in React, Vue, or Angular. Build scalable component-based UIs.

radarAxes.label: UI/UX
radarAxes.title: UI/UX & Accessibility
radarAxes.description: Design implementation, responsive layouts, and accessibility (WCAG) standards.

radarAxes.label: Performance
radarAxes.title: Web Performance
radarAxes.description: Core Web Vitals optimization, loading speed, and user experience metrics.

easy: Strengthen your React fundamentals and component design
Practice building UI components from scratch
Polish your HTML/CSS skills for responsive layouts
doable: Build a solid DSA foundation - solve 50+ LeetCode problems
Master React hooks and state management basics
Create 2-3 frontend projects showcasing your skills
challenging: DSA practice is critical - aim for 100+ problems across patterns
Deep dive into React performance optimization
Build impressive portfolio projects with clean code
stretch: Plan for 6+ months of dedicated preparation
Master DSA and frontend fundamentals thoroughly
Consider gaining more hands-on experience first

rounds.name: Online Assessment
points: 2-3 frontend coding problems focusing on DOM manipulation and algorithms
Common topics: arrays, strings, basic recursion, and object manipulation
May include MCQs on HTML, CSS, JavaScript fundamentals
Time management is key - aim to complete all problems

rounds.name: Machine Coding Round
points: Build a complete UI component from scratch (e.g., autocomplete, infinite scroll, image carousel)
Focus on clean code, component structure, and vanilla JS or React
Demonstrate responsive design and cross-browser compatibility
Working functionality matters more than pixel-perfect design

rounds.name: Technical Interview (DSA)
points: 1-2 easy-to-medium DSA problems with live coding
Focus on arrays, strings, hash maps, and basic tree traversal
Explain your approach and discuss time/space complexity
May include JavaScript-specific questions (closures, promises, event loop)

rounds.name: Technical Interview (Frontend)
points: Deep dive into React concepts: hooks, state management, component lifecycle
Questions on CSS (Flexbox, Grid, responsive design techniques)
Browser fundamentals: event bubbling, rendering process, performance
Build a small component live and explain your design choices

rounds.name: Hiring Manager / Cultural Fit
points: Discussion about past projects and your role in them
Behavioral questions on teamwork, learning, and handling feedback
Why this company and role? Show genuine interest
Ask thoughtful questions about team structure and growth opportunities

easy: Keep practicing DSA regularly to stay sharp
Network and seek referrals to improve chances
doable: DSA fundamentals are essential - solve 75+ problems
Master React and modern frontend tooling
Prepare for machine coding rounds with timed practice
challenging: Strong DSA is mandatory - aim for 120+ problems
Deep understanding of React internals and optimization
Referrals significantly improve your chances - start networking
stretch: This requires 6-8 months of focused preparation
DSA mastery is non-negotiable at this level
Consider building more experience before targeting unicorns

rounds.name: Online Assessment
points: 3-4 coding problems ranging from easy to medium difficulty
Focus on JavaScript problem-solving and algorithmic thinking
May include frontend-specific challenges (DOM manipulation, async operations)
Passing score typically 60-70% to proceed to interviews

rounds.name: DSA Round 1
points: 1-2 medium problems on arrays, strings, or hash maps
Expected to arrive at optimal solution with hints
Code on shared editors like CoderPad or HackerRank
Interviewer evaluates problem-solving approach and communication

rounds.name: DSA Round 2 / Frontend Fundamentals
points: Could be another DSA round or deep dive into JavaScript internals
Topics: closures, prototypes, event loop, promises, this keyword
Questions on React: virtual DOM, reconciliation, hooks, performance
Write code to demonstrate concepts (e.g., implement Promise.all)

rounds.name: Machine Coding / UI Round
points: Build a real-world component: search with autocomplete, pagination, filters
Use React or vanilla JavaScript based on company preference
Focus on code organization, reusability, and edge case handling
Bonus points for responsive design and accessibility considerations

rounds.name: Hiring Manager / Bar Raiser
points: Behavioral questions using STAR format (Situation, Task, Action, Result)
Deep dive into your best project - technical decisions and trade-offs
Questions about handling challenges, tight deadlines, and collaboration
Culture fit assessment - research company values beforehand

easy: Focus on HTML, CSS, and JavaScript fundamentals
Practice basic coding problems for aptitude tests
Prepare clear explanations of your projects
doable: Strengthen your core frontend skills - HTML, CSS, JS
Learn React basics and build simple applications
Practice common interview questions and coding basics
challenging: Solid understanding of web fundamentals is essential
Build a few portfolio projects to showcase
Focus on communication and explaining concepts clearly
stretch: Focus on fundamentals over advanced concepts
This should be very achievable with basic preparation

rounds.name: Aptitude & Online Test
points: Quantitative aptitude, logical reasoning, and verbal ability
1-2 easy coding problems (basic loops, conditionals, arrays)
MCQs on HTML, CSS, JavaScript basics
Focus on accuracy over speed - cutoff-based filtering

rounds.name: Technical Interview 1
points: Questions on HTML tags, CSS selectors, and JavaScript syntax
Explain concepts: var vs let vs const, event delegation, box model
Simple coding: reverse a string, find duplicates in array
Project discussion - be ready to explain your contributions clearly

rounds.name: Technical Interview 2
points: Deeper dive into JavaScript: closures, hoisting, callbacks
Basic React questions if it's on your resume: JSX, props, state
May ask to build a simple layout or debug existing code
Focus on fundamentals - breadth over depth

rounds.name: HR Interview
points: Standard questions: strengths, weaknesses, why this company
Career goals and willingness to learn new technologies
Salary expectations (be realistic for fresher roles)
Relocation flexibility and notice period discussion

easy: Maintain strong DSA practice - solve problems regularly
Prepare for frontend system design discussions
Practice behavioral interviews with STAR format
doable: DSA is the primary filter - solve 150+ LeetCode problems
Master React, performance optimization, and web fundamentals
Build impressive portfolio projects with production quality
challenging: DSA mastery is mandatory - aim for 200+ problems (medium/hard)
Deep frontend system design knowledge is expected
Strong referrals are almost essential - network actively
stretch: This is the highest bar - plan for 6+ months of intense prep
DSA at expert level is non-negotiable
Consider building 1-2 years of experience first

rounds.name: Recruiter Screen
points: Initial call to verify your background and interest
Overview of the interview process and timeline
Questions about visa status, location preferences, start date
Opportunity to ask about the team and role expectations

rounds.name: Phone/Online Technical Screen
points: 1-2 coding problems on shared editor (CoderPad, Google Docs)
Medium difficulty - arrays, strings, hash maps, or trees
Focus on clean code, edge cases, and optimal time complexity
Strong communication is essential - think out loud throughout

rounds.name: Onsite: Coding Round 1
points: Medium to hard DSA problem with live whiteboard or code editor
Common topics: dynamic programming, trees, graphs, recursion
Interviewer evaluates problem breakdown and optimization
Expect follow-up questions to extend or modify your solution

rounds.name: Onsite: Coding Round 2
points: Another DSA problem, potentially harder or different domain
May involve advanced data structures or complex logic
Write clean, bug-free code under time pressure
Discuss multiple approaches before settling on implementation

rounds.name: Onsite: Frontend System Design
points: Design a frontend system: autocomplete, infinite scroll, feed
Cover component architecture, state management, API design
Discuss performance: lazy loading, code splitting, caching
Address accessibility, error handling, and edge cases

rounds.name: Onsite: Behavioral / Googleyness
points: Amazon: Leadership Principles with STAR format
Google: Googleyness - collaboration, growth mindset, adaptability
Prepare stories about ownership, conflict, learning from failure
Questions like 'Tell me about a time you had to learn something new quickly'

rounds.name: Hiring Committee & Team Match
points: Google: Packet reviewed by hiring committee for final decision
Amazon: Bar raiser provides independent assessment
Team matching calls to find mutual fit
Process can take 2-4 weeks post-onsite

phases.title: Advanced Architecture & Design Systems

whatYouLearn.title: Design Systems Architecture
whatYouLearn.description: Build scalable component libraries with design tokens, theming, and semantic versioning for multi-team consumption

whatYouLearn.title: Micro-Frontend Patterns
whatYouLearn.description: Module federation, independent deployments, runtime composition, and cross-app communication strategies

whatYouLearn.title: Frontend System Design
whatYouLearn.description: Architect large-scale applications covering component structure, state management, API design, and scalability

phases.target: Design and architect enterprise-scale frontend systems
whyItMatters: Senior engineers are expected to make architectural decisions
Design systems are crucial for scaling teams and products
Micro-frontends solve real problems at unicorns and big tech

phases.title: Performance & Accessibility Mastery

whatYouLearn.title: Core Web Vitals Deep Dive
whatYouLearn.description: Master LCP, INP, CLS optimization through advanced techniques like resource hints, critical CSS, and edge caching

whatYouLearn.title: WCAG 2.1 AA/AAA Compliance
whatYouLearn.description: Implement comprehensive accessibility: screen reader optimization, keyboard navigation, ARIA patterns, and audit tools

whatYouLearn.title: React Server Components & Next.js 14
whatYouLearn.description: Leverage RSC for performance, server actions, streaming SSR, and optimizing bundle sizes for production

phases.target: Build blazing-fast, accessible applications at scale
whyItMatters: Performance directly impacts revenue and user retention
Accessibility is a legal requirement and moral imperative
RSC represents the future of React development

phases.title: Testing Strategy & DevOps for Frontend

whatYouLearn.title: Testing Architecture
whatYouLearn.description: Design comprehensive test strategies: unit, integration, E2E with Playwright/Cypress, visual regression, and performance testing

whatYouLearn.title: CI/CD Pipeline Mastery
whatYouLearn.description: Build automated deployment pipelines, implement feature flags, canary releases, and rollback strategies

whatYouLearn.title: Monorepo Management
whatYouLearn.description: Use Turborepo or Nx for managing multi-package repositories with shared dependencies and optimized builds

phases.target: Establish robust testing and deployment practices
whyItMatters: Testing confidence enables faster feature velocity
Senior engineers own the entire deployment lifecycle
Monorepos are standard at companies managing multiple products

phases.title: Technical Leadership & Influence

whatYouLearn.title: Mentoring & Code Review Excellence
whatYouLearn.description: Develop junior/mid engineers through effective mentoring, constructive code reviews, and knowledge sharing

whatYouLearn.title: Technical Decision Making
whatYouLearn.description: Write Architecture Decision Records (ADRs), evaluate trade-offs, and drive technical strategy aligned with business goals

whatYouLearn.title: Cross-functional Collaboration
whatYouLearn.description: Work effectively with design, product, and backend teams to deliver cohesive user experiences

phases.target: Lead technical initiatives and mentor engineering teams
whyItMatters: Leadership ability is what separates senior from mid-level engineers
Technical influence multiplies your impact beyond individual contributions
Senior roles require strong communication and stakeholder management

projects.title: Enterprise Design System & Component Library
projects.description: Build a production-ready design system with 20+ components, design tokens, theming, Storybook documentation, and NPM package publishing
projects.shortDescription: Complete design system with component library and documentation
projects.fullDescription: Create a comprehensive design system from scratch featuring design tokens for colors/spacing/typography, a library of 20+ reusable React components built with TypeScript, multi-theme support (light/dark/custom), comprehensive Storybook documentation, automated testing, and published as an NPM package. This project demonstrates senior-level skills in component architecture, API design, accessibility, and developer experience.

implementationSteps.title: Setup Design Token System
implementationSteps.description: Create a token-based design system using CSS variables or style-dictionary. Define tokens for colors (primitive + semantic), spacing scale, typography (font families, sizes, weights, line heights), shadows, border radius, and transitions. Set up theming infrastructure supporting light/dark modes. Use TypeScript for type-safe token access. Document token usage guidelines.

implementationSteps.title: Build Core Component Library
implementationSteps.description: Create 20+ production-ready components: Button (variants, sizes, states), Input/TextArea, Select/Dropdown, Checkbox/Radio, Modal/Dialog, Tooltip, Toast/Notification, Tabs, Accordion, Card, Badge, Avatar, Progress Bar, Spinner, Alert. Use compound component patterns where appropriate. Ensure all components are fully typed with TypeScript, support ref forwarding, and accept className for customization.

implementationSteps.title: Implement Accessibility & Testing
implementationSteps.description: Ensure WCAG 2.1 AA compliance for all components: proper ARIA attributes, keyboard navigation, focus management, and screen reader support. Write comprehensive tests: unit tests with Jest/Vitest, component tests with React Testing Library, accessibility tests with jest-axe. Achieve 90%+ code coverage. Add visual regression testing with Chromatic or Percy.

implementationSteps.title: Create Storybook Documentation
implementationSteps.description: Set up Storybook 7+ with MDX documentation. Create stories for each component showing all variants, states, and use cases. Add interactive controls for props. Write detailed usage guidelines, accessibility notes, and code examples. Implement design tokens addon to visualize token system. Set up automatic Storybook deployment to Chromatic or Netlify.

implementationSteps.title: Package & Publish to NPM
implementationSteps.description: Configure build pipeline using Rollup or Vite to generate ESM and CJS bundles. Implement tree-shaking for optimal bundle sizes. Set up semantic versioning and changelog generation. Create comprehensive README with installation, usage, and contribution guidelines. Publish to NPM as a scoped package. Set up CI/CD with GitHub Actions for automated testing and publishing on version tags.

implementationSteps.title: Polish & Developer Experience
implementationSteps.description: Add TypeScript declaration files for excellent IDE autocomplete. Create CodeSandbox/StackBlitz templates for quick experimentation. Set up ESLint and Prettier configurations. Write migration guides for version upgrades. Add performance benchmarks. Create a documentation website showcasing the design system with live examples, guidelines, and best practices.

projects.title: Micro-Frontend Dashboard Platform
projects.description: Build a modular dashboard using micro-frontend architecture with Module Federation, independent deployments, and shared state management
projects.shortDescription: Micro-frontend platform with module federation and independent apps
projects.fullDescription: Create an advanced micro-frontend application using Webpack Module Federation where multiple independent React applications (Analytics, User Management, Settings) are composed into a unified dashboard. Implement shared state management across micro-frontends, cross-app communication, independent CI/CD pipelines, and a shell application that orchestrates everything. This project showcases expertise in large-scale frontend architecture.

implementationSteps.title: Setup Monorepo & Shell Application
implementationSteps.description: Initialize a monorepo using Turborepo or Nx workspace. Create a shell application (host) that will load micro-frontends. Set up Webpack 5 with Module Federation plugin. Configure shared dependencies (React, React-DOM) to avoid duplication. Create routing infrastructure using React Router that supports dynamic loading of micro-frontends. Define contracts/interfaces for micro-frontend communication.

implementationSteps.title: Build Independent Micro-Frontends
implementationSteps.description: Create 3 independent applications: (1) Analytics Dashboard with charts and metrics using Recharts, (2) User Management with CRUD operations and table, (3) Settings panel with preferences. Each app should be a standalone React application with its own package.json, webpack config, and local development server. Configure Module Federation to expose components from each micro-frontend.

implementationSteps.title: Implement Shared State & Communication
implementationSteps.description: Set up cross-app communication using a shared event bus or custom events. Implement shared authentication state using Zustand or Jotai that persists across all micro-frontends. Create a shared authentication service that all apps consume. Handle user session management centrally. Implement pub/sub pattern for apps to communicate without tight coupling.

implementationSteps.title: Configure Independent Deployments
implementationSteps.description: Set up separate GitHub repositories or monorepo packages for each micro-frontend. Create individual CI/CD pipelines using GitHub Actions or GitLab CI. Deploy each app independently to Vercel, Netlify, or S3 + CloudFront. Configure the shell to fetch micro-frontends from different URLs. Implement versioning strategy with manifest files to track deployed versions.

implementationSteps.title: Add Error Boundaries & Fallbacks
implementationSteps.description: Implement React Error Boundaries for each micro-frontend to prevent one app's crash from breaking the entire dashboard. Create loading skeletons for async-loaded apps. Add fallback UI when a micro-frontend fails to load. Implement retry mechanisms and graceful degradation. Add monitoring using Sentry to track errors across all micro-frontends.

implementationSteps.title: Performance & Documentation
implementationSteps.description: Optimize shared chunk strategy to minimize duplicate code. Implement prefetching for micro-frontends to improve perceived performance. Add performance monitoring for module loading times. Write comprehensive architecture documentation: ADRs explaining key decisions, deployment diagrams, and developer onboarding guide. Create a README for each micro-frontend and the shell application.

projects.title: Real-Time Performance Monitoring & Analytics Tool
projects.description: Build a comprehensive web performance monitoring tool that tracks Core Web Vitals, creates custom reports, and provides actionable optimization insights
projects.shortDescription: Performance monitoring dashboard with Core Web Vitals tracking
projects.fullDescription: Create a production-grade performance monitoring tool that integrates with the Web Vitals API to track LCP, INP, CLS, FCP, and TTFB across real user sessions. Build a real-time dashboard with interactive charts, historical trends, and automated performance scoring. Implement resource timing analysis, custom metrics, and integration with analytics platforms. This demonstrates expertise in web performance, data visualization, and building developer tools.

implementationSteps.title: Implement Core Web Vitals Tracking
implementationSteps.description: Integrate web-vitals library to capture LCP, INP, CLS, FCP, and TTFB. Create a client-side SDK that sends metrics to your backend via beacon API. Track additional custom metrics: time to interactive, first input delay, long tasks. Capture device info, browser, connection type, and viewport size. Implement session replay metadata capture (without actual recording). Handle edge cases and ensure metrics don't impact page performance.

implementationSteps.title: Build Real-Time Dashboard UI
implementationSteps.description: Create a dashboard with multiple visualization types: line charts for metric trends over time, distribution histograms showing p50/p75/p95 percentiles, gauge charts for current scores, and comparison views. Use Recharts or Victory for charts. Implement filters by device type, browser, page, and time range. Add real-time updates using WebSocket or polling. Create a performance score calculator based on weighted averages.

implementationSteps.title: Create Analytics Backend
implementationSteps.description: Build a Next.js API or Express backend to receive and store metrics. Use a time-series database like TimescaleDB or InfluxDB for efficient metric storage. Implement aggregation logic to compute percentiles and trends. Create RESTful endpoints for dashboard data. Add authentication for multi-user support. Implement rate limiting and data retention policies. Set up background jobs for daily/weekly report generation.

implementationSteps.title: Add Resource Timing Analysis
implementationSteps.description: Capture and analyze Resource Timing API data for all assets (scripts, styles, images, fonts). Visualize waterfall charts showing request timing breakdown. Identify slow resources and render-blocking assets. Provide recommendations: suggest preload/prefetch, identify oversized assets, detect unused CSS/JS. Create a lighthouse-style scoring system with actionable insights.

implementationSteps.title: Build Alert & Reporting System
implementationSteps.description: Implement threshold-based alerts: email/Slack notifications when metrics exceed targets. Create custom dashboards users can configure. Generate automated weekly performance reports with trends and insights. Add comparison views: before/after deployments, A/B test variants. Implement export functionality for CSV/PDF reports. Add integration with GitHub for automated PR performance checks.

implementationSteps.title: Performance & Production Readiness
implementationSteps.description: Optimize the dashboard itself for performance: code splitting, lazy loading, virtualized lists for large datasets. Implement proper error handling and retry logic for metric collection. Add comprehensive documentation: SDK integration guide, metric definitions, best practices. Deploy the entire stack (frontend + backend) to production. Open source the project on GitHub with detailed README and contribution guidelines.
